sentences.sentence: “On that evening the horses had been exercised and watered as usual, and the stables( 马房 ) were locked up at nine o’clock.
Two of the stable( 马房 ) boys walked up to the trainer’s house, where they had supper in the kitchen, while the third, Ned Hunter, remained on guard.
At a few minutes after nine the maid, Edith Baxter, took him his supper, which consisted of a dish of curried( 咖喱 ) mutton.
She took no liquid, as there was a water-tap in the stables( 马房 ), and it was the rule that the stable( 马房 ) boy on duty should drink nothing else.
The maid carried a lantern with her, as it was very dark and the path ran across the open moor( 荒野 ).
Edith Baxter was within thirty yards of the stables( 马房 ), when a man appeared out of the darkness and called to her to stop.
As he stepped into the circle of yellow light thrown by the lantern she saw that he looked like a gentleman, was dressed in a gray suit, and carried a heavy stick.
She was most impressed, however, by the extreme paleness of his face and by his nervousness.
She thought he might be a little over thirty.
‘Can you tell me where I am?’ he asked. ‘I had almost made up my mind to sleep on the moor( 荒野 ), when I saw the light of your lantern.’
‘You are close to the King’s Pyland( 金斯皮兰，地名 ) training-stables( 马房 ),’ said she.
‘Oh, indeed! What good luck!’ he cried.
‘I understand that a stable( 马房 ) boy sleeps there alone every night.
Perhaps that is his supper which you are carrying to him.
Would you like to earn the price of a new dress?’
He took a piece of paper, folded up, out of his pocket.
‘See that the boy has this tonight, and you shall have the prettiest dress that money can buy.’
She was frightened by the way he was talking, and ran past him to the window through which she usually passed the meals.
It was already opened, and Hunter was seated at the small table inside.
She had begun to tell him of what had happened, when the stranger came up again.
‘Good evening,’ said he, looking through the window.
‘I wanted to have a word with you.’
The girl has sworn that as he spoke she noticed a little folded-up piece of paper in his hand.
‘What business have you here?’ asked the stable( 马房 ) boy.
‘It’s business that may put something into your pocket,’ said the other.
‘You’ve two horses racing the Wessex Cup—Silver Blaze and Bayard.
Give me some good information and I’ll make it worth your while( 酬谢你 ).
Is it a fact that at these handicaps( （给最好的马额外负重的）让步赛 ) Bayard is the more likely to win, and that the stable( 马房 )’s owner has put his money on Bayard?’
‘So, you’re a spy!’ cried the stable( 马房 ) boy.
‘I’ll show you how we treat them in King’s Pyland( 金斯皮兰，地名 ).’
He sprang up and rushed across the stable( 马房 ) to untie the dog.
The girl ran away to the house, but as she ran she looked back and saw that the stranger was leaning( 倚靠 ) through the window.
A minute later, however, when Hunter rushed out with the dog, the man was gone,
and though he ran all round the buildings he could not find any sign of him.”
“One moment,” I asked.
“Did the stable( 马房 ) boy, when he ran out with the dog, leave the door unlocked behind him?”
“Excellent, Watson, excellent!” said my companion.
The importance of the point struck me so strongly that I sent a telegram to Dartmoor yesterday to clear the matter up.
The boy locked the door before he left it.
The window, I may add, was not large enough for a man to get through.
Hunter waited until the other stable( 马房 ) boys had returned, and then sent a message to the trainer and told him what had happened.
Straker was excited at hearing the news, although it does not seem that he realized its true significance.
It left him, however, vaguely uneasy, and Mrs. Straker, waking at one in the morning, found that he was dressing.
She asked him why, and he said that he could not sleep because he was worried about the horses, and was going to walk down to the stables( 马房 ) to see that all was well.
She begged him to remain at home, as it was raining very hard, but he nevertheless put on his raincoat and left the house.
Mrs. Straker awoke at seven in the morning, to find that her husband had not yet returned.
She quickly dressed herself and set off for the stables( 马房 ).
The door was open;
inside, Hunter was sleeping so deeply that he could not be woken up,
Silver Blaze was gone, and there were no signs of Mr( 先生 ). Straker.
The two stable( 马房 ) boys who slept in the loft( 阁楼 ) were quickly woken up.
They had heard nothing during the night, for they are both sound sleepers( 酣睡的人 ).
Hunter was obviously under the influence of some powerful drug, and no sense could be got out of him.
He was left to sleep it off while the two stable( 马房 ) boys, Mrs. Straker, and the maid ran out in search of Straker and the horse.
They still hoped that the trainer had taken out the horse for early exercise,
but on climbing a small hill near the house and looking out over the moor( 荒野 ),
not only could they see no signs of the missing favorite,
but they noticed something which warned them that they were in the presence of a tragedy.
About a quarter of a mile from the stables( 马房 ) John Straker’s raincoat could be seen covering a small bush.
Immediately beyond the raincoat there was a bowl-shaped hollow( 凹陷处，坑洼处 ) in the moor( 荒野 ), and at the bottom of this the dead body of the unfortunate trainer was found.
His head had been smashed( 猛击 ) by a fierce blow from some heavy weapon( 凶器 ),
and he was wounded on the thigh( 大腿 ), where there was a long, clean( 边缘整齐的 ) cut, obviously done by some very sharp instrument.
It was clear, however, that Straker had defended himself against his attackers,
for in his right hand he held a small knife, which was covered with blood up to the handle,
while in his left he held a red and black silk tie.
This tie was recognized by the maid as having been worn on the previous evening by the stranger who had visited the stables( 马房 ).
Hunter, when he finally woke up, was also sure that the tie belonged to the stranger from the previous evening.
He was equally certain that the same stranger had, while standing at the window, drugged his curried( 咖喱 ) mutton,
and so made sure that there was no one to guard the stable( 马房 ).
The footprints of the missing horse could be clearly seen in the mud of the hollow( 凹陷处，坑洼处 ) where Straker had been murdered.
But from that morning the horse has disappeared, and although a large reward has been offered, and all the gypsies( 吉普赛人 ) of Dartmoor are on the alert( 警惕 ), no news has come of him.
Finally, an analysis has shown that the remains of the stable( 马房 ) boy’s supper contain a large quantity of powdered opium( 鸦片 ),
while the people at the house ate the same meal on the same night without any bad effect.
Those are the main facts of the case. I shall now explain what the police have done.
Inspector Gregory, who has taken charge of the case, is an extremely competent( 能干的 ) officer.
If he only had more imagination he might rise to great heights in his profession.
On his arrival he quickly found and arrested the man upon whom suspicion naturally rested.
There was little difficulty in finding him, for he lived in one of those nearby houses which I have mentioned.
His name is Fitzroy Simpson.
He is a man of excellent family and education, who had lost all his money betting on horses,
and who lives now by doing a little quiet book-making in the sporting clubs of London.
An examination of his betting-book shows that he had taken a large number of bets on Silver Blaze.
On being arrested, he said that he had come down to Dartmoor in the hope of getting some information about the King’s Pyland( 金斯皮兰，地名 ) horses,
and also about Desborough, the second favorite, whose trainer was Silas Brown at the Mapleton stables( 马房 ).
He admitted that he had acted as the maid had said,
but declared that he had no evil intention, and had simply wished to get some first-hand information.
When shown his tie and told where it was found, he turned very pale, and was completely unable to explain why it was found in the hand of the murdered man.
His wet clothing showed that he had been out in the storm of the night before,
and his stick was heavy enough to have caused the terrible injuries that had killed the trainer.
On the other hand, there was no wound on his body,
while the state of Straker’s knife would show that at least one of his attackers must have been cut and lost some blood.
There you have it all, Watson, and if you can help me see things any more clearly I shall be very grateful to you.”

article_info.previous: 一匹出色的赛马Silver Blaze失踪了，它的驯马师也被杀害了，收到马主人和督察的电报后，Holmes启程前往马场了解情况。
article_info.share_words: The door was open; inside, Hunter was sleeping so deeply that he could not be woken up, Silver Blaze was gone, and there were no signs of Mr. Straker.

question.cn: 那个陌生人的真正意图是什么？
question.en: What was the real intention of the stranger?

options.cn: 打探一些关于马的信息。
options.en: To ask for some information about the horses.

options.cn: 上门拜访Ross上校以示尊重。
options.en: To pay a visit to Colonel Ross and show his respect.

options.cn: 在King’s Pyland的马厩借宿一晚。
options.en: To stay overnight at the King’s Pyland training-stables.

analysis: 文中提到：“On being arrested, he said that he had come down to Dartmoor in the hope of getting some information about the King's Pyland horses”所以选A。

question.cn: 马倌是如何对待那个陌生人的？
question.en: How did the stable boy treat the stranger?

options.cn: 在他的狗的帮助下，他杀死了陌生人。
options.en: He killed the stranger with the help of his dog.

options.cn: 他拒绝了向陌生人提供任何信息。
options.en: He refused to give any information to the stranger.

options.cn: 他告诉陌生人哪匹马会获胜。
options.en: He told the stranger which horse would win the race.

analysis: 文中提到，在陌生人询问马的信息时，马倌的反应是“‘So, you’re a spy!’ cried the stable boy. ‘I’ll show you how we treat them in King’s Pyland.’ He sprang up and rushed across the stable to untie the dog.”可知马倌没有收下陌生人的钱也拒绝透露关于马的信息，所以选B。

question.cn: 在听到有陌生人出现的消息后，驯马师John Straker的反应是怎样的？
question.en: What was the trainer John Straker’s reaction after hearing the news about the stranger?

options.cn: 他非常担心马的情况，以至于都睡不好。
options.en: He worried about the horse and couldn’t sleep well.

options.cn: 听到这个消息他非常开心。
options.en: He was delightful at hearing the news.

options.cn: 他认为这个消息不重要，因此没怎么注意。
options.en: He thought the news was not important and paid little attention to it.

analysis: 文中提到，在听说有陌生人出现的消息后，John Straker焦虑不安“It left him, however, vaguely uneasy. . . and he said that he could not sleep because he was worried about the horses.”所以选A。

question.cn: 当Mrs. Straker走到马厩时，她发现了什么？
question.en: What did Mrs. Straker find when she reached the stables?

options.en: The dead bodies of Silver Blaze and Mr. Straker.
The dead body of the stable boy Hunter.
Hunter was under the influence of some powerful drug.

analysis: 文中提到“Silver Blaze was gone, and there were no signs of Mr. Straker. The two stable boys who slept in the loft were quickly woken up. . . Hunter was obviously under the influence of some powerful drug.”所以选C。

question.cn: 那条红黑相间的领带是谁的？
question.en: Who did the red and black silk tie belong to?

analysis: 文中提到“This tie was recognized by the maid as having been worn on the previous evening by the stranger who had visited the stables.”所以选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第53天
